channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ex-Defense Secretary Panetta Recounts Frustration With Obama
item.description: In a new memoir, Leon E. Panetta draws a largely respectful portrait of a president who follows a “well-reasoned vision for the country” but also “misses opportunities.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,335 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pope Francis, Opening Meeting on Family Issues, Urges Open Dialogue
item.description: The two-week assembly of bishops is expected to take up issues like divorce and remarrying and could lead to a revision of some church positions.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Foreign Journal: In Gaza’s Rubble, Shelter Arrives for the Destitute
item.description: In a neighborhood hit badly in the war, members of an extended family weigh the prospect of moving from tents into cramped temporary trailers.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Spain Reports First Case of Ebola Contracted Outside West Africa
item.description: A Spanish nurse contracted the virus while treating a missionary who died in a Madrid hospital, Spain’s health ministry said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: ISIS Moves Into Syrian Kurdish Enclave on Turkish Border
item.description: The black Islamic State flag appeared to be flying from one of the taller buildings in the town of Kobani, which has been under assault since mid-September.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KARAM SHOUMALI and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: A Smuggled Girl’s Odyssey of False Promises and Fear
item.description: Cecilia, a 16-year-old Guatemalan seeking a better life in the United States, fell prey to “coyotes,” the smugglers who lure migrants, on a trip that devolved into outright abduction.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: World Briefing: Japanese Men Were Planning to Fight for ISIS, Police Say
item.description: The Tokyo police said Monday that they were investigating several university students suspected of planning to go to Syria to fight for the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Cross-Border Fighting Kills Civilians in Kashmir
item.description: India and Pakistan blamed each other for the fighting that left at least nine civilians dead on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Villagers mourned the death of a relative who they said was killed by shelling from the Pakistani side of the border on Monday in the village of Arnia, in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Israel Protests a Move to Recognize Palestinian State
item.description: Israel fears that Swedish recognition could lead other major European countries to follow suit..
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Carl Magnus Nesser, the Swedish ambassador to Israel, arriving Monday at the Israeli Foreign Affairs Ministry.

item.title: Two in Tehran Are Missing After Explosion Near Military Complex
item.description: Witnesses said an enormous orange flash came from the Parchin military site, although Iranian officials denied that the explosion had occurred there.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Nobel Prize in Medicine is Awarded for Discovery of Brain’s ‘Inner GPS’
item.description: A British-American scientist and two Norwegians were awarded the prize for identifying the cells that help animals determine where they are.
item.dc:creator: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN
item.media:description: John O'Keefe, Edvard Moser, and May-Britt Moser, from left, were announced as winners of the Nobel Prize in Medicine on Monday.

item.title: Greece’s Draft Budget Aims to Ease Austerity Measures
item.description: Unveiling what is essentially the nation’s first balanced budget in decades, the fragile coalition government pledged to lower taxes and increase benefits.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Infographics on Hong Kong Protests Are Circulated in China
item.description: Infographics in Chinese state-run media and social media are drawing attention as the government moves, more confidently, to control the narrative of the Hong Kong protests.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong on Monday. An infographic that depicts the protests as illegal and backed by the United States is being broadcast by Chinese state media, drawing widespread interest in mainland China.

item.title: Rugged Seabed Seen in New Maps Complicates Search for Jet
item.description: Australian officials said they now have a much clearer picture of how difficult the renewed search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner in the depths of the Indian Ocean will be.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Iran Frees Wife of Detained Washington Post Journalist
item.description: Yeganeh Salehi, also a journalist, was released, although her husband, Jason Rezaian, remained in custody. The two were detained in July.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, a reporter for The Washington Post, and his wife, Yeganeh Salehi, were arrested on July 22.

item.title: ISIS’ Ammunition Is Shown to Have Origins in U.S. and China
item.description: An analysis suggests that ammunition transferred into Syria and Iraq to help stabilize governments has instead passed from the governments to the jihadists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A .50-caliber machine gun that France offered to Kurdish pesh merga forces in Iraq last month.

item.title: As Hong Kong Protest Ebbs, Organizers Claim Small Gains
item.description: Leaders of the movement said they had moved the needle, however slightly, toward the possibility of a more democratic future for Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: American Held by ISIS Says He Is ‘Pretty Scared to Die’
item.description: Abdul-Rahman Kassig, 26, was shown last week in a video by the Islamic State that purported to show the execution of a British captive.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Palestine’s ‘Nuclear Option’
item.description: Until Mahmoud Abbas moves toward dissolving the Palestinian Authority, the international community won't take him seriously.
item.dc:creator: By ALI JARBAWI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Dalai Lama Debacle’ Stirs Anger in South Africa
item.description: A decision by South Africa to deny the Dalai Lama a visa to attend a gathering of former Nobel laureates in Cape Town appears to have backfired in a way that is drawing increased scrutiny to China’s heavy-handed tactics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama visiting a school with his fellow Nobel laureates Shirin Ebadi, left, and Jody Williams, in Dharamsala, India.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Newspapers, Pro- and Anti-Beijing, Weigh In on Protests
item.description: While pro-establishment newspaper editorials call on Hong Kong to clamp down on the pro-democracy demonstrations, liberal papers, like Apple Daily, sympathize with the struggle.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Hong Kong prides itself on its press freedom, with its newspapers offering a range of views.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Image of the Hong Kong Protests: ‘Umbrella Man’
item.description: A 12-foot figure of wooden blocks holding a bright yellow umbrella in its outstretched right hand was moved into the protest site in front of government headquarters, evoking the Goddess of Democracy sculpture installed by students in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A new mascot for the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, dubbed Umbrella Man, emerged on Sunday night.

item.title: Protesters in Hong Kong Ease Sit-In Near Government Headquarters
item.description: It was unclear whether the encampments would be abandoned, even as some paths were cleared for government workers to reach their offices.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early Monday morning, some protesters camped out overnight in the Admiralty district. One student said, “I will keep coming back till the police kick us out.”

item.title: Ebola Victim’s Journey From Liberian War to Fight for Life in U.S.
item.description: What began as a joyful reunion — refugees from African civil strife seeking to rebuild their lives in America — spiraled last week into a national health scare.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN SACK
item.media:description: Parishioners, many of them Liberian, prayed for victims of Ebola during a church service in Euless, Tex., on Sunday.
